channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Batley and Spen: Labour narrowly hold seat in by-election
item.description: The result means Kim Leadbeater will represent the seat previously held by her murdered sister Jo Cox.

item.title: Saskia Jones: Family say event organisers should stand down
item.description: They say organisers of an event, where a convicted terrorist killed two people, should step down.

item.title: Bagram: Last US and Nato forces leave key Afghanistan base
item.description: The sprawling airbase has been the centre of operations against the Taliban and al-Qaeda for almost 20 years.

item.title: Asda to allow permanent hybrid working for offices
item.description: The supermarket says most of its 4,000 head office staff can choose to work at home or other locations.

item.title: Love Island: ITV condemns deaths threats sent to contestant Chloe Burrows
item.description: Messages sent to contestant Chloe Burrows online were "wholly unacceptable", the broadcaster says.

item.title: NHS pay: England senior doctors could take industrial action over 1% rise
item.description: Consultants will be consulted on industrial action if the 1% pay rise offer is not improved, says union.

item.title: Boris Johnson to welcome Angela Merkel for last UK visit as Germany's leader
item.description: The German chancellor will also meet the Queen at Windsor Castle on her final official visit to Britain.

item.title: Harry Dunn death: Parents 'speak for him' in US damages case
item.description: Charlotte Charles and Tim Dunn face lawyers acting on behalf of Anne Sacoolas in the US.

item.title: Asylum queue nine times longer than 10 years ago
item.description: There are 65,000 people waiting for asylum decisions from the UK government, figures suggest.

item.title: Canada Lytton: Heatwave record village overwhelmingly burned in wildfire
item.description: The village of Lytton this week recorded the country's highest ever temperature of 49.6C (121.3F).

item.title: Vaccine hesitancy: Your job or the jab?
item.description: Health workers once on the frontline of the pandemic are now embroiled in a row over vaccine mandates.

item.title: The Papers: 'Reunited for Diana' and 'Freedom Day warning'
item.description: Friday's papers include a statue of Diana, and the PM's warning over plans for lifting England's lockdown.

item.title: Pride Month: Labour MP Dan Carden on alcohol addiction
item.description: An MP gives an emotional speech on his family's support as he battled his alcohol addiction.

item.title: Personal Independence Payments: 'Have I less than six months to live?'
item.description: The government is accused of creating a 'two tier welfare system' for people who have terminal illnesses by two charities.

item.title: Miami building collapse: 'People went to sleep, and then they died'
item.description: Both the mother and grandmother of Pablo Rodríguez were in the building when it fell. Now, he wants answers.

item.title: Lebanon’s ‘suffocating’ energy crisis
item.description: Six-year-old Sedra is one of the people whose lives have been put at risk by the country's energy crisis.

item.title: Euro 2020: The England fan who invited Stormzy round after the Germany game
item.description: Conal O'Leary was watching the football with his mates when Stormzy turned up.

item.title: Los Angeles fireworks explosion: Truck goes up in flames as police seize fireworks
item.description: A truck filled with 2,000kg of fireworks goes up in flames, injuring at least 17 people in Los Angeles.

item.title: Batley and Spen: Fraught by-election concludes in dramatic fashion
item.description: How drama built as Labour retained its Batley and Spen seat by a narrow margin.

item.title: Parents of children called Alexa challenge Amazon
item.description: Youngsters are being bullied over their name - also the default wake word for the tech firm's smart speakers.

item.title: Turkey's plastics ban: Where does the UK send its waste now?
item.description: Turkey is due to ban most plastic waste sent from the UK, so tonnes of packaging will need a new home.

item.title: A Cambodian village ripped apart by a bad batch of rice wine
item.description: At least 30 Cambodians died recently in less than a month after drinking toxic home-brewed alcohol.

item.title: Bobby Gillespie and Jehnny Beth: 'Brexit has destroyed any hope for young musicians'
item.description: Bobby Gillespie and Jehnny Beth on culture wars, and why Utopian Ashes is not a break-up record.

item.title: Hampstead Heath: How the 'lungs of the metropolis' remained unblackened
item.description: If a Victorian-era landowner hadn't been thwarted, Hampstead Heath as we know it might not exist.

item.title: How airlines will stop you losing your bags in the future
item.description: In 2019, 25.4 million bags went missing, costing the industry billions of dollars - can big data solve the problem?

item.title: Fear Street and Goosebumps author RL Stine: 'I find horror very funny'
item.description: He says it was a "shock" seeing Fear Street being adapted for a grown-up audience on Netflix.

item.title: Britain's Raducanu, 18, into Wimbledon third round
item.description: Eighteen-year-old British wildcard Emma Raducanu stuns 2019 French Open finalist Marketa Vondrousova in straight sets to reach the Wimbledon third round.

item.title: Curran stars as England comfortably beat Sri Lanka again
item.description: England comfortably beat Sri Lanka again in the second one-day international at The Oval to clinch the series with a game to spare.

item.title: Cavendish wins 32nd Tour de France stage to close within two of Merckx's all-time record
item.description: Mark Cavendish's resurgence continues as he claims his 32nd stage win at the Tour de France to move closer to the all-time record of 34 held by Belgian legend Eddy Merckx.

item.title: Warholm breaks Young's 29-year-old 400m hurdles world record
item.description: Norway's Karsten Warholm runs 46.70 to set a new world record in the 400m hurdles in front of his home crowd at the Diamond League meeting in Oslo.

item.title: Meet the Kordas: youngest member of a sporting dynasty prepares to face GB's Evans
item.description: On Sunday, Sebastian Korda's sister Nelly won the Women's PGA Championship. Now he's preparing to face Dan Evans at Wimbledon.

item.title: Wimbledon 2021: Roger Federer, Coco Gauff and Daniil Medvedev in day four best bits
item.description: Watch some of the best bits from day four at Wimbledon including an incredible shot by Coco Gauff and a pocket mishap on court two.

item.title: Euro 2020 and Covid: How can I watch with my friends?
item.description: Wembley will host 60,00 fans next week, but millions will be watching on TV at home and in pubs.

item.title: The EU’s 'vaccine passport' and what it means for travel
item.description: The EU's Digital Covid Certificate is being rolled out across all 27 nations.

item.title: What are the social distancing rules and when could they end?
item.description: It's not clear whether we will still have to wear masks and socially distance once lockdown eases.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The progress made in vaccinating the country's adult population, as almost 45 million people have received at least one dose.

item.title: How many cases are in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: British Jews' fear and defiance amid record monthly anti-Semitism reports
item.description: Some 460 anti-Semitic incidents were reported to the Community Security Trust from 8 May to 7 June.

item.title: Covid quarantine hotels: Women say they were sexually harassed by guards
item.description: One woman tells the BBC a security guard employed by G4S mimed sex while they were alone in a lift.

item.title: A fake wedding, and a $250,000 scam
item.description: How a British man's dreams of a future with his Ukrainian fiancee ended in financial disaster.

item.title: The Lazarus heist: How North Korea almost pulled off a billion-dollar hack
item.description: In 2016 North Korean hackers planned a $1bn raid on Bangladesh's national bank and came within an inch of success. But how did they do it?
